page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 51: Line 51:
Thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday, 28 January,<ref name="Friday of Anger">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/be97d4a8-2b0b-11e0-a65f-00144feab49a.html#axzz1CMDTT7Ao|title=Pent-Up Anger Bursts on to Cairo Streets|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|work=[[Financial Times]] }}</ref> called by some the "Friday of Anger" ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ç§umÊ¿at al-Ä¡aá¸ab}}'' {{IPA-arz|ËgomÊet elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|lang}})<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Andrew Sullivan|Sullivan, Andrew]]|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/01/awaiting-the-friday-of-anger.html|title=Awaiting the 'Friday Of Anger'|publisher=''[[The Daily Dish]]'' ([[blog]] of ''[[The Atlantic]]'')|date=|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> and by others as the "Day of Rage".<ref>Issacharoff, Avi (28 January 2011). [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/egypt-anti-government-protesters-declare-friday-day-of-rage-1.339629 "Egypt Anti-Government Protesters Declare Friday 'Day of Rage']. ''[[Haaretz]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41288680/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/ "Egypt Protesters, Police Brace for 'Day of Rage'"]. 27 January 2011. ''[[MSNBC]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref> Shortly before 1:00, hours ahead of the protests, the Egyptian government shut down Internet services,<ref name="aljazeera-272">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html|title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabist.net/blog/2011/1/28/urgent-egypt-has-shut-off-the-internet.html|title=Urgent: Egypt Has Shut Off the Internet|publisher=Arabist|last=El Amrani|first=Issandr|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=18 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/hack/2011/01/egypt-tor-use-skyrocketing-as.php|title=Egypt: Tor Use Skyrocketing as Users Route-Around Internet Blocks|work=[[ReadWriteWeb]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> although some people communicated using a [[text-to-speech]] telephone service set up by [[Google]] and [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessandleadership.com/technology/item/28137-google-twitter-launch-alte|title=Google, Twitter launch alternative service in Egypt |work=[[Business and Leadership]]|date=|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> [[Text messaging]] and [[mobile phone]] services also appeared to be blocked.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&iref=BN1|title=Violent Clashes Erupt During Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> According to [[Vodafone]], all mobile operators in Egypt were instructed to suspend services in selected areas. The authorities had prior legislative approval to issue such an order.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/press.html|title=Press|publisher=[[Vodafone]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref>
Thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday, 28 January,<ref name="Friday of Anger">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/be97d4a8-2b0b-11e0-a65f-00144feab49a.html#axzz1CMDTT7Ao|title=Pent-Up Anger Bursts on to Cairo Streets|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|work=[[Financial Times]] }}</ref> called by some the "Friday of Anger" ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ç§umÊ¿at al-Ä¡aá¸ab}}'' {{IPA-arz|ËgomÊet elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|lang}})<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Andrew Sullivan|Sullivan, Andrew]]|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/01/awaiting-the-friday-of-anger.html|title=Awaiting the 'Friday Of Anger'|publisher=''[[The Daily Dish]]'' ([[blog]] of ''[[The Atlantic]]'')|date=|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> and by others as the "Day of Rage".<ref>Issacharoff, Avi (28 January 2011). [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/egypt-anti-government-protesters-declare-friday-day-of-rage-1.339629 "Egypt Anti-Government Protesters Declare Friday 'Day of Rage']. ''[[Haaretz]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41288680/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/ "Egypt Protesters, Police Brace for 'Day of Rage'"]. 27 January 2011. ''[[MSNBC]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref> Shortly before 1:00, hours ahead of the protests, the Egyptian government shut down Internet services,<ref name="aljazeera-272">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html|title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabist.net/blog/2011/1/28/urgent-egypt-has-shut-off-the-internet.html|title=Urgent: Egypt Has Shut Off the Internet|publisher=Arabist|last=El Amrani|first=Issandr|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=18 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/hack/2011/01/egypt-tor-use-skyrocketing-as.php|title=Egypt: Tor Use Skyrocketing as Users Route-Around Internet Blocks|work=[[ReadWriteWeb]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> although some people communicated using a [[text-to-speech]] telephone service set up by [[Google]] and [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessandleadership.com/technology/item/28137-google-twitter-launch-alte|title=Google, Twitter launch alternative service in Egypt |work=[[Business and Leadership]]|date=|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> [[Text messaging]] and [[mobile phone]] services also appeared to be blocked.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&iref=BN1|title=Violent Clashes Erupt During Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> According to [[Vodafone]], all mobile operators in Egypt were instructed to suspend services in selected areas. The authorities had prior legislative approval to issue such an order.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/press.html|title=Press|publisher=[[Vodafone]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Mohandeseen protests.jpg|thumb|left|The up-scale [[Mohandessin|Mohandeseen]] district in [[Giza]] during the Friday of Anger. Violent clashes occurred here between the protesters and the security forces which occupied the bridge on the left, involving stone-throwing, [[Molotov cocktails]], rubber bullets and tear gas grenades.]]
[[File:Mohandeseen protests.jpg|thumb|left|The up-scale [[Mohandessin|Mohandeseen]] district in [[Giza]] during the Friday of Anger. Violent clashes occurred here between the protesters and the security forces which occupied the bridge on the left, involving stone-throwing, [[Molotov cocktails]], rubber bullets and tear gas grenades.]]
  +
[[File:NDP HQ on fire.jpg|thumb|left|The main headquarters of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] aflame during ''Friday of Anger'' in Cairo]]
[[File:Destroyed Central Security Forces vehicle.jpg|thumb|Police vehicle that was burned during the night of 28 January]]
[[File:Destroyed Central Security Forces vehicle.jpg|thumb|Police vehicle that was burned during the night of 28 January]]
Line 65: Line 66:
''Al Jazeera'' reported an ''[[Associated Press]]'' claim that an elite counterterrorism force had been deployed at strategic points around [[Cairo]], and that Egypt's interior ministry was warning of "decisive measures". The secretary-general of the ruling National Democratic Party, [[Safwat Sherif]], held a press conference stating, "We hope that tomorrow's Friday prayers and its rituals happen in a quiet way that upholds the value of such rituals...and that no one jeopardises the safety of citizens or subjects them to something they do not want."<ref name="aljazeera2">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
''Al Jazeera'' reported an ''[[Associated Press]]'' claim that an elite counterterrorism force had been deployed at strategic points around [[Cairo]], and that Egypt's interior ministry was warning of "decisive measures". The secretary-general of the ruling National Democratic Party, [[Safwat Sherif]], held a press conference stating, "We hope that tomorrow's Friday prayers and its rituals happen in a quiet way that upholds the value of such rituals...and that no one jeopardises the safety of citizens or subjects them to something they do not want."<ref name="aljazeera2">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
â
[[File:NDP HQ on fire.jpg|thumb|left|The main headquarters of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] aflame during ''Friday of Anger'' in Cairo]]
 
Amid reports of looting, concerns were raised about the safety of the antiquities of the famous [[Egyptian Museum]], near the epicenter of the Cairo protests. Egyptian state television announced in the evening that army commandos had secured the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Army Secures Museum with Pharaonic Treasures|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/arts-us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70R7K820110128|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters joined soldiers in protecting the museum, situated beside the burning ruling party headquarters.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-291-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Jan 29 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref> Looters managed to enter during the night from the roof to damage a number of small artifacts, and it was initially reported that they had ripped the heads off two mummies, but subsequent reports claimed that Egypt's top archaeologist had mistaken skulls from other skeletons, and that the mummies were intact.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Looters Destroy Mummies in Egyptian Museum|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70S1YU20110129|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011|first=Yasmine|last=Saleh}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=By Christopher Torchia |url=http://www.buffalonews.com/wire-feeds/24-hour-world-news/article329931.ece |title=AP Interview: Egypt declares treasures safe - 24 Hour World News |publisher=The Buffalo News |date=2011-02-01 |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref>
Amid reports of looting, concerns were raised about the safety of the antiquities of the famous [[Egyptian Museum]], near the epicenter of the Cairo protests. Egyptian state television announced in the evening that army commandos had secured the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Army Secures Museum with Pharaonic Treasures|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/arts-us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70R7K820110128|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters joined soldiers in protecting the museum, situated beside the burning ruling party headquarters.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-291-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Jan 29 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref> Looters managed to enter during the night from the roof to damage a number of small artifacts, and it was initially reported that they had ripped the heads off two mummies, but subsequent reports claimed that Egypt's top archaeologist had mistaken skulls from other skeletons, and that the mummies were intact.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Looters Destroy Mummies in Egyptian Museum|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70S1YU20110129|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011|first=Yasmine|last=Saleh}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=By Christopher Torchia |url=http://www.buffalonews.com/wire-feeds/24-hour-world-news/article329931.ece |title=AP Interview: Egypt declares treasures safe - 24 Hour World News |publisher=The Buffalo News |date=2011-02-01 |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref>
